Recognizing the relationships between the moving parts of the web like IP addresses and URLs makes the overall browsing experience more rewarding, and helps you make smart choices about the content you consume and share online.

weblit-Privacy.intro: Your personal information is valuable. That’s why it’s vital that you are the one in charge of controlling how your personal information gets shared. That way, you can take steps to prevent others from tracking you, using your data in ways you don’t like, or spying on you without your knowledge or consent. This page includes steps anyone can take to make their online lives more private and secure. It also explores some of the larger ideas and debates around privacy, trust and your digital footprint.

discover.title: See who’s tracking you online
links: Watch the video. As you surf the Web, information is being collected about you. This “Tracking the Trackers” TED Talk video explains how.
Try it for yourself. Install the Lightbeam add-on to see for yourself. Shine a light on who’s watching your online activities.

discover.title: Tell sites you don’t want to be tracked
links:
Enable “Do Not Track.” You can tell sites to stop tracking your browsing history using this simple change to your browser settings. Here’s how:

  • Firefox
  • Internet Explorer
  • Safari
  • Chrome
  • Opera

discover.title: How to turn on private browsing
links: If you don’t want anyone with physical access to your computer to see what you’re doing online, you can enable “private browsing.” This deletes cookies, temporary Internet files and browsing history after you close the window.

discover.title: See how much your personal data is worth to marketers
links: How much buyers would pay for your information? Use this interactive calculator from the Financial Times to find out.

discover.title: Adjust your social network settings
links: Facebook—Click the settings cog in the upper right corner of your screen, then click Privacy Settings >> “Who can see my stuff.”
Twitter—click the settings cog, then “Settings.” You can adjust settings like adding or removing your location to tweets, or make your tweets private so that only people you approve can see them.
Google+—go to Home >> Settings to adjust who can interact with you, comment on your posts, or start a conversation.

discover.title: Learn more about surveillance and spying
links: NSA Files Decoded: What the revelations mean for you. The Guardian newspaper’s interactive exploration on what the National Security Agency is collecting about you.
Learn more about your own meta-data. What social networks, devices and services do you use? What meta-data does that reveal about you to the NSA and others?

discover.title: Thinking about your digital footprint and reputation

Making choices about what to post or share—sharing things online is what makes the web great. But sharing embarrassing or personal things about yourself or your friends can come back to haunt you. This short video walks you through it.
Over-sharing, identity and respect. WNYC’s Radio Rookies interview youth and others about over-sharing, online identity, responsibility, sexism and more.

make.title: Make a music video about privacy, surveillance or online freedom
make.description:
Use Popcorn Maker to make a video. You could use videos you find on the web, music, pictures, animated GIFs or your own voice commentary.

  • “Party at the NSA.“ Check out this example from @keyboardkat. Then remix it to make it your own.
  • Or make your own from scratch. This guide walks you through how to use Popcorn Maker for the first time.

make.title: Write about who’s tracking your online
make.description: Use Lightbeam to gather research about who’s tracking you online. Or do research about government surveillance. Then tell a story about what you’ve learned. You could publish it as a web page with Thimble, make a multimedia essay with Popcorn, or just write a blog post or tweet about it.

make.title: Host a “crypto-party” for you and your friends
make.description:
There are various things you can do to make your online data more secure. Some are harder than others. If you want to take extra steps to protect your communications, here are some ways to go further.

  • Install HTTPS Everywhere. A collaboration between The Tor Project and Electronic Frontier Foundation, this extension encrypts your communications to make your browsing more secure.
  • Learn more about the Tor Project. If you’re more ambitious, you can use tools like Tor to defend yourself against network surveillance and traffic analysis. Here’s how to get started. Or check out The Guardian’s explanation on Tor works.
  • Volunteer with Tor. Tor is a free network that relies on bandwidth donated by volunteers around the world. Want to help? This guide and video show you how.
  • Host a crypto-party. Now that you’ve learned how to encrypt your data, why not help others? This “CryptoParty” guide can help. You can also add your event to Mozilla’s Maker Party to join others hosting web literacy parties around the world.

weblit-OpenPractices.intro: How do we spread ideas? To help the network grow and to let new ideas flourish, the web is based on open standards that can be studied, reused and improved by anyone. Licenses define what’s possible with the code and content we find online, and understanding how they work allows you to participate in the web’s evolution.
